dublin_core.dcvalue: Providers at the University of California San Francisco UCSF Medical Center have been able to significantly improve door to needle times for stroke patients by using a real time text message intervention to routinely inform all members of the stroke care team about the door to needle time for every stroke patient who receives thrombolytic therapy Administrators say the approach has slashed average door to needle times by at least 20 minutes The Stroke Center medical director follows up with team members for every patient who does not receive tPA within the recommended 60 minute time frame to find out what the impediment was To be successful administrators say the intervention needs to include real time feedback a mechanism for accountability and sustained effort
ED management : the monthly update on emergency department management
Text-message-driven intervention, real time feedback slashes time-to-treatment for stroke patients.
